q: What are the risks of cyclospora?
a: You can get cyclospora from drinking unclean water or eating food that has not been cooked thoroughly or washed with clean water. Cyclospora is found in parts of Central and South America, south and southeast Asia, the Middle East, and Africa. You cannot catch it from close contact with someone who has it.

q: How can I avoid cyclospora while traveling?
a: If you’re traveling to an area where cyclospora is found, there are things you can do to reduce the chances of getting it. Do wash your hands with soap and clean water or alcohol hand gel regularly, only drink bottled, boiled or purified water, and only eat food that has been cooked thoroughly or cleaned with bottled, boiled or purified water. Don’t eat raw fruit and vegetables that have not been washed in bottled, boiled or purified water, have ice in your drinks, or drink tap water or use it to clean your teeth.

q: What are the symptoms of cyclospora?
a: Not everyone with cyclospora gets symptoms. If you do get symptoms, they usually start about a week after getting infected. Symptoms of cyclospora include diarrhea, loss of appetite and weight loss, stomach cramps, bloating and farting, tiredness, feeling sick, and muscle aches.

q: When should I seek urgent medical advice regarding cyclospora?
a: You should ask for an urgent GP appointment or get help from NHS 111 if you have diarrhea and you've recently traveled to an area where cyclospora is found, have diarrhea for more than 7 days, or have bloody diarrhea or bleeding from your bottom. You can call 111 or get help from 111 online. If you're still abroad, get medical advice where you are as soon as possible.

q: How long does cyclospora usually last?
a: Cyclospora usually gets better on its own within a few days or weeks. Make sure you have lots of fluids to avoid dehydration. Sometimes you may be asked to provide a sample of poo (stool sample) so it can be checked for cyclospora. If your symptoms are severe or do not go away, you may need antibiotics.

q: What website can I check the risks of a country I'm traveling to?
a: You can check the risks of a country you're traveling to on the TravelHealthPro website.

q: How is cyclospora transmitted?
a: Cyclospora is transmitted through drinking unclean water or eating food that has not been cooked thoroughly or washed with clean water. It is not transmitted through close contact with someone who has it.

q: Is cyclospora a contagious infection?
a: No, cyclospora is not contagious. It cannot be caught through close contact with someone who has it.

a: If you have diarrhea after traveling to an area where cyclospora is found, you should ask for an urgent GP appointment or get help from NHS 111. You can also call 111 or get help from 111 online. If you're still abroad, get medical advice where you are as soon as possible.

q: Can cyclospora be treated with antibiotics?
a: If your symptoms are severe or do not go away, you may need antibiotics. However, cyclospora usually gets better on its own within a few days or weeks. It is important to stay hydrated and drink plenty of fluids.
